attributes.title: Depressed affect and the framing effect

q1.value: Depressed affect and the framing effect

q3.value: Does depressed affect influence risky decisions? A recent study examined how depressed affect relates to decision making with gains and losses when decisions are made under time-pressure. In two experiments with alternatives framed as gains, Byrne, Willis, Peters, Kunkel, and Tibbett (2020) found that participants with more depressed affect made more risky decisions under time pressure, but there was no relationship between depressed affect and decision making without time pressure. A third experiment had alternatives framed as losses and found that participants with more depressed affect made fewer risky decisions without time pressure, but there was no relationship between depressed affect and decision making under time pressure. Thus, with no time limit, depressed affect does not relate to decision making with gain, but it is related to fewer risky choices with losses. This should result in a smaller framing effect as depressed affect increases. The purpose of the present study was to examine how depressed affect relates to decision making with gains and losses in the same experiment using more complex problems.

q4.value: We predict that depressed affect will be related to less preference toward the risky alternative with loss problems (but not with gain problems). This will result in the framing effect being negatively correlated with depressed affect. We also predict there will be a framing effect overall (risk preference will be greater with loss problems than it will be with gain problems).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: There is one within-subjects IV with two levels: frame (gain or loss). The DV is the preference rating toward the risky alternative.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to two versions of the framing problems. The versions will differ in which specific problems have positive frames and which have negative frames. The order of the 10 problems will also be randomly determined for each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will collect data from Mechanical Turk workers. They will be paid for participation. The study should take about 15 minutes to complete.

q13.value: We will collect data from at least 462 participants who meet inclusion criteria.

q14.value: In a previous study with different materials, the relationship between the framing effect and depressed affect was r = .13. Using G*Power, we determined that we would need 462 participants to have a power of .80 to detect this effect (with two-tailed alpha = .05).

q15.value: We will collect data from 500 people and then determine how many of them met inclusion criteria. If there are fewer than 462, we will continue running batches of 50 participants until we have 462 who met inclusion criteria.

question.value: There is one IV (frame) with two levels (gain and loss).

We will measure participants' preference between two options on a 6 point scale (strongly prefer option A to strongly prefer option B). Option B will always be the risky option, so we will refer to these as risk preference scores. 
We will also measure depressed affect using 7 items from the CES-D.

We will compute the framing effect for each person by taking the risk preference score for losses and subtracting the risk preference score for gains. A larger value represents a larger framing effect.

We will run a series of correlations between depressed affect scores and 1) risk preference for gains, 2) risk preference for losses, and 3) framing effect. We will also examine if there is an overall framing effect with a matched-samples t-test using risk preference scores for gains and losses.

q21.value: We will use alpha = .05 for all analysis and reject null hypotheses when p < alpha.

q22.value:
We will exclude data from participants who:
1) state that they responded to some questions without reading them
2) have no variability in the responses to the framing problems
3) skip more than two framing problems
4) skip more than one depressed affect question

q23.value: We will leave missing responses out of the means for their respective condition for framing problems or depressed affect scale.

attributes.title: Directed Forgetting of Incidental Learned Information: Stimulus-Response Associations

q2.value: Hannah Dames, Marco Ragni, Andrea Kiesel, Christina U. Pfeuffer

q3.value:
Whereas various studies have already demonstrated that humans are able to intentionally forget previously learned information (as often measured using the directed forgetting, short DF, paradigm, for an overview see Pastötter, Tempel, & Bäuml, 2017), only few studies have analyzed whether DF affects motor representations (Tempel & Frings, 2016) or incidentally learned information (e.g., Hockley, Ahmad, & Nicholson, 2016; Jou, 2010). 

Humans are able to intentionally forget previously learned information: In the list-method of DF (for an overview see Pastötter, Tempel, & Bäuml, 2017), for instance, participants are instructed to sequentially learn two lists of items. After learning the first list (referred to as L1), participants are either instructed to forget or to continue remembering this list before learning list 2 (L2). In a memory test for both lists (regardless of the forget or remember condition), two findings can be observed: Participants in the forget condition recall fewer L1 items (L1 forgetting) and more L2 items (L2 enhancement) as compared to the remember condition.

Recent studies provided first evidence that typical findings on retrieval-induced forgetting and effects of DF on subsequent learning extend to motor memory (in particular, motor sequences, Tempel, Aslan, & Frings, 2016; Tempel & Frings, 2013, 2016) and stimulus-response (S-R) associations (Dreisbach & Bäuml, 2014). The current study aims to gain a deeper understanding of the mechanisms underlying the DF effect on not explicitly instructed and implicitly tested S-R associations. For this, we will investigate whether (not explicitly instructed) learned S-R associations can be intentionally forgotten by employing a DF paradigm that allows the simultaneous measurement of S-R retrieval. 


Our study will consist of three major phases: A learning phase, a distraction phase, and a test phase. 

During the learning phase, the participants’ task is to categorize images of objects of two lists (L1 and L2) as containing a mechanism or not and to remember the images. Extending the DF paradigm to S-R mappings using an arbitrary categorization task (drawing on an item-specific priming paradigm; Hsu & Waszak, 2012; Moutsopoulou, Yang, Desantis, & Waszak, 2015; Pfeuffer, Moutsopoulou, Pfister, Waszak, & Kiesel, 2017), this will enable participants to learn S-R associations (stimulus-action, S-A, associations according to the terminology provided by Moutsopoulou et al., 2015). Importantly, whether a left or right response is required for the classification of a specific stimulus differs across the stimuli and is indicated by a task-cue regarding the classification-response mapping prior to the stimulus presentation. For example, the task cue “M + N” indicates that an object image has to be classified as mechanic by pressing a left key and a right key for the classification “non-mechanic”. Conversely, the task cue “N +M” indicates that a right key press is required for mechanic objects and a left key press for non-mechanic ones.

Between L1 and L2, half of the participants will be instructed to forget the objects of L1 using a cover-story (forget condition). The other half of the participants will be told to continue remembering the objects and to proceed to the second list (remember condition).
Following a distractor task, participants solve a visual working memory task for three minutes to spurge short-term memory.

In the test phase, participants are presented with all the object images from the learning phase (L1 and L2 regardless of the remember or forget condition) and new object images. Participants are again instructed to classify objects as containing a mechanism or not. However, for half of the old objects (presented in the learning phase), the S-R associations are the same as they had been in the learning phase (Response repetitions). For the other half of the old objects, the S-R associations are the opposite of what they had been in the learning phase (item-specific response switches). 

Response switches are therefore defined as item-specific switches of the item-specific S-R mappings between the learning (object requires a left key press in the four learning trials of the learning phase ) and the test phase (object requires a right key press in the one test trial of the test phase ). Response repetitions are in turn defined as item-specific repetitions between the learning (object requires a left key press in the four learning trials of the learning phase) and the test phase (object also requires a left key press in the one test trial of the test phase), respectively. 

We then use the difference in response times, RTs, and error rates between trials that require a response switch and response repetition trials as a measure of how DF affects both the formation of novel S-R associations as well as how already formed, competing or not competing, S-R associations may or may not influence the responses given in the test phase.

In a typical memory test for L1 and L2 in the list-method of DF, two findings can be observed: Participants in the forget condition recall fewer L1 items (L1 forgetting) and more L2 items (L2 enhancement) as compared to the remember condition.

Applying these observations to the context of S-R associations we expect the following observations: If DF influences the persisting activation of the competing S-R associations, the performance difference between response repetition and switch trials should be smaller in the forget as compared with the remember condition for to-be-forgotten L1 items (L1 forgetting). If DF enhances the learning of novel S-R associations, then, the performance difference between response repetition and switch trials should be greater in the forget as compared with the remember condition for L2 items (L2 enhancement).

q4.value:
Item-specific repetition priming effects describe a typical decrease in RTs and error rates for item-specific response repetitions (see the introduction) between learning phase and test phase trials as compared to response switches. If item-specific S-R associations are formed during the learning phase and are automatically retrieved in the test trial, responses during the test phase should be slower and les accurate for response switches as compared to response repetitions. However, we expect, that in the forget condition, these item-specific repetition priming effects are reduced for items from the to-be-forgotten list 1 (L1) and increased for list 2 (L2):

H1a (L1 forgetting): The item-specific repetition priming effect of RTs (increased RTs for response switches as compared to response repetitions in the test phase) for L1 stimuli is smaller in the forget condition as compared with the remember condition. 

H1b (L1 forgetting): The item-specific repetition priming effect of error rates for L1 stimuli (increased error rates for response switches as compared to response repetitions in the test phase) is smaller in the forget condition as compared with the remember condition. 

H2a (L2 enhancement): The item-specific repetition priming effect of RTs in the test phase for L2 stimuli is stronger in the forget as compared to the remember condition. 

H2b (L2 enhancement): The item-specific repetition priming effect of error rates in the test phase for L2 associations is stronger in the forget as compared to the remember condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The experiment has a 2 x 2 design with item-specific response (repetition vs. switch) manipulated within participants and instruction (remember vs. forget condition) manipulated between participants. 

The experiment will be conducted in German. Images of objects serve as stimuli and denote everyday objects. The participants’ task is to classify the stimuli as containing a mechanism or not (“mechanisch”, Engl. mechanical and “nicht-mechanisch”, Engl. nonmechanical) using a left or right response key. 

The trial structure is as follows: First, a fixation cross is presented (700 ms) including a task-cue that indicates whether a left or right response is required for the classification of a specific stimulus. For example, the task-cue “M + N” indicates that an object image has to be classified as “mechanic” by pressing a left key and a right key for the classification “non-mechanic”. Conversely, the task cue “N +M” indicates that a right key press is required for mechanic objects and a left key press for non-mechanic ones.

Then, the stimulus (the image of an object) follows. Participants are instructed to classify the object as containing a mechanism or not by pressing the response key (left vs. right) that spatially corresponds to previously presented task-cue mapping. Objects are displayed until a response (classifications via left/right key presses) is given but for a maximum of 2000 ms. Next, a feedback screen is presented informing participants about their response´s correctness (500 ms; “richtig!”/ Eng: “correct!” for correct responses; “Fehler!”/ Eng.: “error!” for incorrect responses). Responses that are outside the response frame are aborted with corresponding feedback (“zu langsam!”/ Eng: “too slow!”, 500 ms).

Importantly, whether a left or right response is required for the classification of a specific stimulus differs across the stimuli as indicated the task-cue. Thereby, for each specific item participants learn item-specific associations between each stimulus (object image) and the corresponding response (left or right key-press): The participants learns items-specific S-R associations (stimulus-action, S-A, associations according to the terminology provided by Moutsopoulou et al., 2015). 

In order to build stronger S-R associations, each stimulus is presented four times with the same S R mapping in the learning phases.

Participants are randomly assigned to either the remember condition or the forget condition (38 each). As described, there are three major phases: A learning phase (consisting of L1 and L2 as well as the remember/ forget instruction in-between L1 and L2), a distraction phase, and a test phase.  

Instructions are given on the screen and summarized by an experimenter. After receiving the instructions regarding the classification task (see task description), participants are told to also remember the images of objects they classify. Crucially, participants are not instructed to learn any associations between the images and their responses.

In a practise block consisting of eight additional object images, participants are familiarized with the task.

Learning phase. The learning phase consists of two lists, list 1 (L1) and list 2 (L2) enabling participants to learn (not explicitly instructed) stimulus-response (S-R) associations. 
In total, they respond to 32 objects in L1 (presented 4 times, thus, 128 trials), 32 different objects in L2 (presented 4 times, thus, 128 trials). In L1 and L2, each stimulus is paired with the corresponding response four times: L1 and L2 each consist of four blocks and in each block the stimuli of the corresponding list are presented once (and thus four times in total).

First, participants respond to all items in L1 in the four corresponding blocks. After and in-between L1 and L2, half of the participants are either instructed to forget or to remember L1. Thus, for participants in the forget condition, L1 consists of to-be-forgotten items (to measure L1 forgetting) and L2 of to-be-remembered items (to measure L2 enhancement). For the remember condition, both L1 and L2 consist of to-be-remembered items. 

Forget-condition: After L1 is learned, participants in the forget condition are instructed to forget the so-far-presented items. For this, after L1, a computer screen gives an arbitrary overview of the participant’s performance and the current condition group the experiment was in. The participants are asked to go to the experimenter in order to continue the experiment in the next condition group. The experimenter then steps in, reads over the summary and apologizes for having accidentally started the experiment in the incorrect condition group. Thereupon, the experimenter leaves the room pretending to ask the leading researcher what to do next. The experimenter re-enters the room and informs the participants that they could restart the experiment in the correct condition group. The participants are kindly asked to start over again with the correct condition group. The participants are casually told to try to forget what they had just done (i.e., to forget the images but importantly no instruction is given on the S-R mappings). The experiment is restarted and the participants are again instructed to forget everything they have previously learned. The instruction emphasizes the importance of trying to forget the previously presented objects and only to concentrate on the subsequently to-be-categorized objects. The practice trials are skipped by the experimenter. 

Remember-condition. After L1 is learned, a screen is presented providing participants with the same arbitrary experimental overview as in the forget condition. Again, the experimenter has to enter the room to continue the experiment. In contrast to the forget condition, however, this time the participants are simply told that they finished the first part of the learning phase and are going to continue with the second part.

Both groups then respond to all items in L2 in the four corresponding blocks.

Distractor phase. In a following distractor phase intended to purge short-term memory, participants solve a visual working memory task for three minutes. 
Test phase. In the test phase, participants are then presented with all objects from the learning phase (L1 and L2 regardless for both the remember or forget condition, thus, 64 old objects) and 64 new objects (total of 128 trials). Again, participants are instructed to classify the objects as containing a mechanism or not by pressing a left/right key (the same task as in the learning phase). Per list (L1/L2), for half of the stimuli the required response was the same as in the learning phase (response repetition; see introduction), whereas it switches for the other half of the objects (response switches). Items in the test phase are presented once.
 
Using post-experimental questions, we will check whether participants had any suspicion about the restart of the experiment. Participants are properly debriefed about the simulated experiment restart and the reason behind this deception. Last, they are asked not to tell friends and colleagues about the simulated experiment restart.

q9.value:
Participants are randomly assigned to either the remember condition or the forget condition (n = 38 each). 

Images of objects are drawn from a pool of 128 images that contains 32 stimuli of small and mechanical objects, 32 stimuli of large and mechanical objects, 32 stimuli of small and nonmechanical objects, and 32 stimuli of large and nonmechanical objects (256 pixels X 256 pixels, about 8° visual angle). For the presentation of stimuli, for each participant three lists are randomly drawn from this pool of stimuli without replacement: 

-one list of items for L1 (learning phase) containing 32 different objects with 16 mechanic and 16 non-mechanic objects 
-one list of items for L2 (learning phase) containing 32 different objects with 16 mechanic and 16 non-mechanic objects – different objects than in L1
-one list of items for the test phase consisting of all old objects (L1 and L2 objects) as well as additional 32 mechanic and 32 non-mechanic novel objects

In the learning phase, assignments of response key mappings for each stimulus (mechanic/non-mechanic – left/right) are randomized across participants but are constrained in a way that for each participant, each classification (mechanic vs. non-mechanic) will equally often require a left or a right key response. 

As described, in L1 as well as L2, each stimulus is paired with the corresponding response four times: L1 and L2 each consist of four blocks and in each block the stimuli of the corresponding list are presented once (and thus four times in total). While the response key mapping for each stimulus remains the same across the four repetition blocks for the stimuli in L1 as well as across the four repetition blocks for the stimuli in L2, the order of presented stimuli is independently randomized in each block. 

In the test phase, old items are randomly assigned to require either a response switch or repetition with the following constraint: 50% of the old L1 items require a response switch, the other 50% of the old L1 require a response repetition; 50% of the old L2 items require a response switch, the other 50% of the old L2 require a response repetition, respectively. The order of the presented stimuli (old and new) in the test-phase is randomized trial-by-trial for every participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via a local web-based study participation platform where participants can sign up for studies they qualify for on the system. In exchange for their participation, participants will receive monetary compensation (the expected duration is 45 minutes, 6 EUR).

q14.value: In two experiments conducted by Dreisbach and Bäuml (2014), a partial eta squared of ηp2 = .14 and ηp2 = .06 was observed for the critical interaction between instruction (forget vs. remember) and compatibility (in the current study: item-specific action, repetition vs. switch) in the RT analyses (see analysis plan). Power analyses using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) on the mean ηp2 = .10 suggested a sample size of N=76 to detect a significant effect (with α = .05 with 1-β = .80).

question.value: Item-specific required action (repetition vs. switch) of trials in the test phase, instruction (forget vs. remember condition), list (L1 vs. L2)

We will measure reaction times and error rates of items from L1 and L2 in the test phase.

In addition, we will collect some demographic data (e.g., age, gender) and information on participants’ motivation at the end of the experiment. However, we will not use these measures in confirmatory analyses. Last, using post-experimental questions, we will assess whether participants had any suspicion about the restart of the experiment.

For the RTs analysis, for L1 and L2 items separately, we will fit a linear mixed model (LMM) on participants’ RTs in the test phase with item-specific response (repetition vs. switch, within) and instruction (remember vs. forget condition, between) as well as the corresponding interaction as fixed effects and the maximal random effects structure . The maximal random effects structure for our design is given by random intercepts for participants and objects and by-participant random slopes for action (repetition vs. switch) and by object random slopes for action and instruction (and their interaction). In case the models do not converge, we will first remove the correlation among random slopes and then stepwise remove random slopes (beginning with by-object random slopes) until the models converge. For the analyses of errors, we will fit a generalized mixed model (GLMM) on participants’ responses’ correctness in the test phase with item-specific action (repetition vs. switch, within) and instruction (remember vs. forget condition, between) as well as the corresponding interaction as fixed effects separated for L1 and L2 items with binomial errors distribution and a logistic linking function. Otherwise, the procedure will be the same as for the RT analyses.

q21.value: For the RT analysis and the LMM, we will evaluate the significance of the fixed effect using the Kenward-Roger approximation to estimate the denominator degrees of freedom with the standard p > .05 criterion. For the GLMM and the error analyses, we will use parametric bootstrap comparisons.

q22.value: The following exclusion criteria on a participant level (participants who will be completely excluded from the analysis) will be applied: First, participants who report that they did not follow the instructions (e.g., using only one instead of both hands to respond) will not be considered in the analyses. Second, participants will be excluded from all analyses when they committed errors or response omissions in more than 30% of the trials in the learning or test phase. All these participants will be replaced by new ones. On a trial level (trials that will be excluded but the participants remain for the analysis) the following data will be excluded: First, trials with response omissions will be discarded. Second, for the analyses of trials in the test phase only the trials with correct responses in the corresponding trials in the learning phase will be used. Third, trials with exceptionally high or low RTs that is, trials with RTs above/below 3SD from the individual cell mean will be discarded. Participants who then have less than six observations per cell will also be excluded from the analyses and will be replaced. In addition, the trials from the practice blocks will be removed. Using post-experimental questions, we will check whether participants had any suspicion about the restart of the experiment. All participants excluded by the means of these exclusion criteria will be directly replaced.

q23.value: Participants who do not complete the whole experiment will be excluded and directly replaced.

q25.value:
*References*

Dreisbach, G., & Bäuml, K. H. T. (2014). Don’t do it again! Directed forgetting of habits. Psychological Science, 25(6), 1242–1248. https://doi.org/10.1177/0956797614526063 

Hockley, W. E., Ahmad, F. N., & Nicholson, R. (2016). Intentional and incidental encoding of item and associative information in the directed forgetting procedure. Memory & Cognition, 44(2), 220–228. https://doi.org/10.3758/s13421-015-0557-8 

Hsu, Y. F., & Waszak, F. (2012). Stimulus-classification traces are dominant in response learning. International Journal of Psychophysiology, 86(3), 262–268. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijpsycho.2012.10.002

Jou, J. (2010). Can associative information be strategically separated from item information in word-pair recognition? Psychonomic Bulletin & Review, 17(6), 778–783. https://doi.org/10.3758/PBR.17.6.778 

Moutsopoulou, K., Yang, Q., Desantis, A., & Waszak, F. (2015). Stimulus–classification and stimulus–action associations: Effects of repetition learning and durability. The Quarterly Journal of Experimental Psychology, 68(9), 1744–1757. https://doi.org/10.1080/17470218.2014.984232

Pastötter, B., Tempel, T., & Bäuml, K. H. T. (2017). Long-term memory updating: The reset-of-encoding hypothesis in list-method directed forgetting. Frontiers in Psychology, 8, 2076. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2017.02076 

Pfeuffer, C. U., Moutsopoulou, K., Pfister, R., Waszak, F., & Kiesel, A. (2017). The power of words: On item-specific stimulus–response associations formed in the absence of action. Journal of Experimental Psychology: Human Perception and Performance, 43(2), 328–347. https://doi.org/10.1037/xhp0000317

Tempel, T., Aslan, A., & Frings, C. (2016). Competition dependence of retrieval-induced forgetting in motor memory. Memory & Cognition, 44(4), 671–680. https://doi.org/10.3758/s13421-015-0578-3 

Tempel, T., & Frings, C. (2013). Resolving interference between body movements: Retrieval-induced forgetting of motor sequences. Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition, 39(4), 1152–1161. https://doi.org/10.1037/a0030336  

Tempel, T., & Frings, C. (2016). Directed forgetting benefits motor sequence encoding. Memory & Cognition, 44(3), 413–419. https://doi.org/10.3758/s13421-015-0565-8

The current study aims to gain a deeper understanding of the mechanisms underlying the DF effect on not explicitly instructed and implicitly tested S-R associations. For this, we will investigate whether (not explicitly instructed) learned S-R associations can be intentionally forgotten by employing a DF paradigm that allows the simultaneous measurement of S-R retrieval. 


Our study will consist of three major phases: A learning phase, a distraction phase, and a test phase. 

During the learning phase, the participants’ task is to categorize images of objects of two lists (L1 and L2) as containing a mechanism or not and to remember the images. Extending the DF paradigm to S-R mappings using an arbitrary categorization task (drawing on an item-specific priming paradigm; Hsu & Waszak, 2012; Moutsopoulou, Yang, Desantis, & Waszak, 2015; Pfeuffer, Moutsopoulou, Pfister, Waszak, & Kiesel, 2017), this will enable participants to learn S-R associations (stimulus-action, S-A, associations according to the terminology provided by Moutsopoulou et al., 2015). Importantly, whether a left or right response is required for the classification of a specific stimulus differs across the stimuli and is indicated by a task-cue regarding the classification-response mapping prior to the stimulus presentation. For example, the task cue “M + N” indicates that an object image has to be classified as mechanic by pressing a left key and a right key for the classification “non-mechanic”. Conversely, the task cue “N +M” indicates that a right key press is required for mechanic objects and a left key press for non-mechanic ones.

Between L1 and L2, half of the participants will be instructed to forget the objects of L1 using a cover-story (forget condition). The other half of the participants will be told to continue remembering the objects and to proceed to the second list (remember condition).
Following a distractor task, participants solve a visual working memory task for three minutes to spurge short-term memory.

In the test phase, participants are presented with all the object images from the learning phase (L1 and L2 regardless of the remember or forget condition) and new object images. Participants are again instructed to classify objects as containing a mechanism or not. However, for half of the old objects (presented in the learning phase), the S-R associations are the same as they had been in the learning phase (Response repetitions). For the other half of the old objects, the S-R associations are the opposite of what they had been in the learning phase (item-specific response switches). 

Response switches are therefore defined as item-specific switches of the item-specific S-R mappings between the learning (object requires a left key press in the four learning trials of the learning phase ) and the test phase (object requires a right key press in the one test trial of the test phase ). Response repetitions are in turn defined as item-specific repetitions between the learning (object requires a left key press in the four learning trials of the learning phase) and the test phase (object also requires a left key press in the one test trial of the test phase), respectively. 

We then use the difference in response times, RTs, and error rates between trials that require a response switch and response repetition trials as a measure of how DF affects both the formation of novel S-R associations as well as how already formed, competing or not competing, S-R associations may or may not influence the responses given in the test phase.

In a typical memory test for L1 and L2 in the list-method of DF, two findings can be observed: Participants in the forget condition recall fewer L1 items (L1 forgetting) and more L2 items (L2 enhancement) as compared to the remember condition.

Applying these observations to the context of S-R associations we expect the following observations: If DF influences the persisting activation of the competing S-R associations, the performance difference between response repetition and switch trials should be smaller in the forget as compared with the remember condition for to-be-forgotten L1 items (L1 forgetting). If DF enhances the learning of novel S-R associations, then, the performance difference between response repetition and switch trials should be greater in the forget as compared with the remember condition for L2 items (L2 enhancement).
registration_responses.q4:
Item-specific repetition priming effects describe a typical decrease in RTs and error rates for item-specific response repetitions (see the introduction) between learning phase and test phase trials as compared to response switches. If item-specific S-R associations are formed during the learning phase and are automatically retrieved in the test trial, responses during the test phase should be slower and les accurate for response switches as compared to response repetitions. However, we expect, that in the forget condition, these item-specific repetition priming effects are reduced for items from the to-be-forgotten list 1 (L1) and increased for list 2 (L2):

H1a (L1 forgetting): The item-specific repetition priming effect of RTs (increased RTs for response switches as compared to response repetitions in the test phase) for L1 stimuli is smaller in the forget condition as compared with the remember condition. 

H1b (L1 forgetting): The item-specific repetition priming effect of error rates for L1 stimuli (increased error rates for response switches as compared to response repetitions in the test phase) is smaller in the forget condition as compared with the remember condition. 

H2a (L2 enhancement): The item-specific repetition priming effect of RTs in the test phase for L2 stimuli is stronger in the forget as compared to the remember condition. 

H2b (L2 enhancement): The item-specific repetition priming effect of error rates in the test phase for L2 associations is stronger in the forget as compared to the remember condition.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9:
Participants are randomly assigned to either the remember condition or the forget condition (n = 38 each). 

Images of objects are drawn from a pool of 128 images that contains 32 stimuli of small and mechanical objects, 32 stimuli of large and mechanical objects, 32 stimuli of small and nonmechanical objects, and 32 stimuli of large and nonmechanical objects (256 pixels X 256 pixels, about 8° visual angle). For the presentation of stimuli, for each participant three lists are randomly drawn from this pool of stimuli without replacement: 

-one list of items for L1 (learning phase) containing 32 different objects with 16 mechanic and 16 non-mechanic objects 
-one list of items for L2 (learning phase) containing 32 different objects with 16 mechanic and 16 non-mechanic objects – different objects than in L1
-one list of items for the test phase consisting of all old objects (L1 and L2 objects) as well as additional 32 mechanic and 32 non-mechanic novel objects

In the learning phase, assignments of response key mappings for each stimulus (mechanic/non-mechanic – left/right) are randomized across participants but are constrained in a way that for each participant, each classification (mechanic vs. non-mechanic) will equally often require a left or a right key response. 

As described, in L1 as well as L2, each stimulus is paired with the corresponding response four times: L1 and L2 each consist of four blocks and in each block the stimuli of the corresponding list are presented once (and thus four times in total). While the response key mapping for each stimulus remains the same across the four repetition blocks for the stimuli in L1 as well as across the four repetition blocks for the stimuli in L2, the order of presented stimuli is independently randomized in each block. 

In the test phase, old items are randomly assigned to require either a response switch or repetition with the following constraint: 50% of the old L1 items require a response switch, the other 50% of the old L1 require a response repetition; 50% of the old L2 items require a response switch, the other 50% of the old L2 require a response repetition, respectively. The order of the presented stimuli (old and new) in the test-phase is randomized trial-by-trial for every participant.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q14: In two experiments conducted by Dreisbach and Bäuml (2014), a partial eta squared of ηp2 = .14 and ηp2 = .06 was observed for the critical interaction between instruction (forget vs. remember) and compatibility (in the current study: item-specific action, repetition vs. switch) in the RT analyses (see analysis plan). Power analyses using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) on the mean ηp2 = .10 suggested a sample size of N=76 to detect a significant effect (with α = .05 with 1-β = .80).
registration_responses.q21: For the RT analysis and the LMM, we will evaluate the significance of the fixed effect using the Kenward-Roger approximation to estimate the denominator degrees of freedom with the standard p > .05 criterion. For the GLMM and the error analyses, we will use parametric bootstrap comparisons.
registration_responses.q22: The following exclusion criteria on a participant level (participants who will be completely excluded from the analysis) will be applied: First, participants who report that they did not follow the instructions (e.g., using only one instead of both hands to respond) will not be considered in the analyses. Second, participants will be excluded from all analyses when they committed errors or response omissions in more than 30% of the trials in the learning or test phase. All these participants will be replaced by new ones. On a trial level (trials that will be excluded but the participants remain for the analysis) the following data will be excluded: First, trials with response omissions will be discarded. Second, for the analyses of trials in the test phase only the trials with correct responses in the corresponding trials in the learning phase will be used. Third, trials with exceptionally high or low RTs that is, trials with RTs above/below 3SD from the individual cell mean will be discarded. Participants who then have less than six observations per cell will also be excluded from the analyses and will be replaced. In addition, the trials from the practice blocks will be removed. Using post-experimental questions, we will check whether participants had any suspicion about the restart of the experiment. All participants excluded by the means of these exclusion criteria will be directly replaced.
registration_responses.q23: Participants who do not complete the whole experiment will be excluded and directly replaced.

registration_responses.q8.question:
The experiment has a 2 x 2 design with item-specific response (repetition vs. switch) manipulated within participants and instruction (remember vs. forget condition) manipulated between participants. 

The experiment will be conducted in German. Images of objects serve as stimuli and denote everyday objects. The participants’ task is to classify the stimuli as containing a mechanism or not (“mechanisch”, Engl. mechanical and “nicht-mechanisch”, Engl. nonmechanical) using a left or right response key. 

The trial structure is as follows: First, a fixation cross is presented (700 ms) including a task-cue that indicates whether a left or right response is required for the classification of a specific stimulus. For example, the task-cue “M + N” indicates that an object image has to be classified as “mechanic” by pressing a left key and a right key for the classification “non-mechanic”. Conversely, the task cue “N +M” indicates that a right key press is required for mechanic objects and a left key press for non-mechanic ones.

Then, the stimulus (the image of an object) follows. Participants are instructed to classify the object as containing a mechanism or not by pressing the response key (left vs. right) that spatially corresponds to previously presented task-cue mapping. Objects are displayed until a response (classifications via left/right key presses) is given but for a maximum of 2000 ms. Next, a feedback screen is presented informing participants about their response´s correctness (500 ms; “richtig!”/ Eng: “correct!” for correct responses; “Fehler!”/ Eng.: “error!” for incorrect responses). Responses that are outside the response frame are aborted with corresponding feedback (“zu langsam!”/ Eng: “too slow!”, 500 ms).

Importantly, whether a left or right response is required for the classification of a specific stimulus differs across the stimuli as indicated the task-cue. Thereby, for each specific item participants learn item-specific associations between each stimulus (object image) and the corresponding response (left or right key-press): The participants learns items-specific S-R associations (stimulus-action, S-A, associations according to the terminology provided by Moutsopoulou et al., 2015). 

In order to build stronger S-R associations, each stimulus is presented four times with the same S R mapping in the learning phases.

Participants are randomly assigned to either the remember condition or the forget condition (38 each). As described, there are three major phases: A learning phase (consisting of L1 and L2 as well as the remember/ forget instruction in-between L1 and L2), a distraction phase, and a test phase.  

Instructions are given on the screen and summarized by an experimenter. After receiving the instructions regarding the classification task (see task description), participants are told to also remember the images of objects they classify. Crucially, participants are not instructed to learn any associations between the images and their responses.

In a practise block consisting of eight additional object images, participants are familiarized with the task.

Learning phase. The learning phase consists of two lists, list 1 (L1) and list 2 (L2) enabling participants to learn (not explicitly instructed) stimulus-response (S-R) associations. 
In total, they respond to 32 objects in L1 (presented 4 times, thus, 128 trials), 32 different objects in L2 (presented 4 times, thus, 128 trials). In L1 and L2, each stimulus is paired with the corresponding response four times: L1 and L2 each consist of four blocks and in each block the stimuli of the corresponding list are presented once (and thus four times in total).

First, participants respond to all items in L1 in the four corresponding blocks. After and in-between L1 and L2, half of the participants are either instructed to forget or to remember L1. Thus, for participants in the forget condition, L1 consists of to-be-forgotten items (to measure L1 forgetting) and L2 of to-be-remembered items (to measure L2 enhancement). For the remember condition, both L1 and L2 consist of to-be-remembered items. 

Forget-condition: After L1 is learned, participants in the forget condition are instructed to forget the so-far-presented items. For this, after L1, a computer screen gives an arbitrary overview of the participant’s performance and the current condition group the experiment was in. The participants are asked to go to the experimenter in order to continue the experiment in the next condition group. The experimenter then steps in, reads over the summary and apologizes for having accidentally started the experiment in the incorrect condition group. Thereupon, the experimenter leaves the room pretending to ask the leading researcher what to do next. The experimenter re-enters the room and informs the participants that they could restart the experiment in the correct condition group. The participants are kindly asked to start over again with the correct condition group. The participants are casually told to try to forget what they had just done (i.e., to forget the images but importantly no instruction is given on the S-R mappings). The experiment is restarted and the participants are again instructed to forget everything they have previously learned. The instruction emphasizes the importance of trying to forget the previously presented objects and only to concentrate on the subsequently to-be-categorized objects. The practice trials are skipped by the experimenter. 

Remember-condition. After L1 is learned, a screen is presented providing participants with the same arbitrary experimental overview as in the forget condition. Again, the experimenter has to enter the room to continue the experiment. In contrast to the forget condition, however, this time the participants are simply told that they finished the first part of the learning phase and are going to continue with the second part.

Both groups then respond to all items in L2 in the four corresponding blocks.

Distractor phase. In a following distractor phase intended to purge short-term memory, participants solve a visual working memory task for three minutes. 
Test phase. In the test phase, participants are then presented with all objects from the learning phase (L1 and L2 regardless for both the remember or forget condition, thus, 64 old objects) and 64 new objects (total of 128 trials). Again, participants are instructed to classify the objects as containing a mechanism or not by pressing a left/right key (the same task as in the learning phase). Per list (L1/L2), for half of the stimuli the required response was the same as in the learning phase (response repetition; see introduction), whereas it switches for the other half of the objects (response switches). Items in the test phase are presented once.
 
Using post-experimental questions, we will check whether participants had any suspicion about the restart of the experiment. Participants are properly debriefed about the simulated experiment restart and the reason behind this deception. Last, they are asked not to tell friends and colleagues about the simulated experiment restart.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be recruited via a local web-based study participation platform where participants can sign up for studies they qualify for on the system. In exchange for their participation, participants will receive monetary compensation (the expected duration is 45 minutes, 6 EUR).
registration_responses.q16.question: Item-specific required action (repetition vs. switch) of trials in the test phase, instruction (forget vs. remember condition), list (L1 vs. L2)
registration_responses.q17.question:
We will measure reaction times and error rates of items from L1 and L2 in the test phase.

In addition, we will collect some demographic data (e.g., age, gender) and information on participants’ motivation at the end of the experiment. However, we will not use these measures in confirmatory analyses. Last, using post-experimental questions, we will assess whether participants had any suspicion about the restart of the experiment.
registration_responses.q19.question: For the RTs analysis, for L1 and L2 items separately, we will fit a linear mixed model (LMM) on participants’ RTs in the test phase with item-specific response (repetition vs. switch, within) and instruction (remember vs. forget condition, between) as well as the corresponding interaction as fixed effects and the maximal random effects structure . The maximal random effects structure for our design is given by random intercepts for participants and objects and by-participant random slopes for action (repetition vs. switch) and by object random slopes for action and instruction (and their interaction). In case the models do not converge, we will first remove the correlation among random slopes and then stepwise remove random slopes (beginning with by-object random slopes) until the models converge. For the analyses of errors, we will fit a generalized mixed model (GLMM) on participants’ responses’ correctness in the test phase with item-specific action (repetition vs. switch, within) and instruction (remember vs. forget condition, between) as well as the corresponding interaction as fixed effects separated for L1 and L2 items with binomial errors distribution and a logistic linking function. Otherwise, the procedure will be the same as for the RT analyses.

attributes.title: Causal effects of psychedelic drug use on political attitudes and ethical consumerism

q1.value: Causal effects of psychedelic drug use on political attitudes and ethical consumerism

q3.value: Though there is correlational evidence to suggest that psychedelic drug use is associated with political perspectives, nature relatedness, and the personality traits of openness and conscientiousness, the direction of causality still remains unknown. To test whether psychedelic drug use causes changes in political attitudes, we will analyse specific variables that were collected as part of a large naturalistic observational study assessing what factors are most influential in determining how people will respond to psychedelic drugs. In this study, volunteers who took part in a psychedelic session/ceremony/experience through their own initiative completed a large battery of questionnaires at six timepoints: once days before the psychedelic session/ceremony/experience took place; once immediately before; once within two days of the session/ceremony/experience taking place; and three more times over the following two years. We will test whether psychedelic drug users experienced changes in political perspectives and attitudes towards ethical consumerism two-weeks and four-weeks afterwards, and whether these changes correlated with changes in empathy, compassion, mindfulness and the personality trait of openness.

q4.value:
H1: Frequency of lifetime psychedelic use at baseline will correlate positively with liberal political perspectives and ethical consumerism scores.

H2a: Psychedelic drug users will have more liberal political perspectives and higher ethical consumerism scores after taking part in the psychedelic session/ceremony/experience relative to pre-experience baseline scores. 
H2b: The effects of psychedelic drug use on political perspectives and ethical consumerism will be stronger for novices, who had little to no previous experience using psychedelics, than for experts who had significant previous experience using psychedelics.
H2c: The effects of psychedelic drug use on political perspectives and ethical consumerism will be greater in participants with lower baseline scores on liberalism, anti-authoritarianism and ethical consumerism.

H3a: Changes in pre-post levels of empathy, compassion, mindfulness and openness (but not conscientiousness, agreeableness, extraversion and neuroticism) will be correlated with changes in political perspectives and ethical consumerism.
H3b: The effects of psychedelic drug use on political perspectives and ethical consumerism will be mediated by changes in ego dissolution during the experience.
H3c: The mediation effect described in H3b will be greater for novices than experts.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Observational (pre-post, longitudinal) Study

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q11.value: Data was collected as part of a larger study investigating what factors are most influential in determining how people will respond to psychedelic drugs. As of the date of submission, some of the data relevant to the research plan have been accessed and analyzed by the members of the research team who are based at Imperial College London. Crucially, however, the data relevant to the research plan (but no additional data) have not been accessed by the preregistration entrants: Simonsson (University of Oxford) and Marks (University College London).

question.value:
Psychedelic drug users intent on having a psychedelic experience through their own initiative were informed about the online questionnaire. Volunteers were recruited by posting a link on several online platforms, leading to a website created for this project (www.psychedelicsurvey.com). This website contained information about the study and its purpose, what was expected from the participants and it provided the opportunity to sign up for the study. After reading the study information, individuals who were willing to participate enrolled themselves in the study by declaring informed consent (button click) and entering the expected date of their psychedelic experience.

Participants were measured on six occasions: 1) One week before the psychedelic session/ceremony/experience was due to take place, or as near to the experience as possible (note, due to travel plans and the potential unavailability of internet, individuals may have needed to complete the baseline measures some time before the experience itself, but crucially, the timing was recorded). At this timepoint, demographic information and baseline trait variables were assessed. 2) Within 0-3 hours of the ceremony/dosing session taking place; state variables concerning set were assessed at this point. 3) Within two days of the session/ceremony/experience took place, to assess the setting of the session/ceremony/experience and the acute psychological effects. 4) Two weeks after the session/ceremony/experience took place, to measure long-term effects. 5) Four weeks after the session/ceremony/experience, the trait variables were assessed again as a follow-up procedure. 6) Approximately 24 months after the session/ceremony/experience, the trait variables were assessed again as a follow-up procedure.

Technology was designed for participants to receive the right questionnaires on the appropriate moments through email notifications. Participants consented to receiving these email prompts during the informed consent process.

q13.value: The aim was to recruit at least 100 participants. However, it was hoped that this number would be exceeded.

question.value:
Demographic information: Age, gender, employment-status

Frequency of lifetime psychedelic use: (categorical response options ranging from 'Never' to '>100 times')

Ego-dissolution: Ego-Dissolution Inventory (EDI) (Nour et al., 2016)

Political perspectives: Political Perspective Questionnaire (PPQ) (self-constructed measure) 

Liberalism to conservatism VAS scale

Anti-authoritarianism to authoritarianism VAS scale

Empathy Interpersonal Reactivity Index (IRI) (Davis, 1983)

Compassion Santa Clara Brief Compassion Scale (SCBCS) (Hwang, Plante, & Lackey, 2008)

Mindfulness Cognitive and Affective Mindfulness Scale – revised (CAMS-R) (Feldman, Hayes, Kumar, Greeson, & Laurenceau, 2007)

A scale was devised to measure concern regarding ethical consumerism. The ethical consumerism scale will be subjected to an exploratory factor analysis using principal component analysis (PCA). The appropriate number of factors to be extracted will be
determined by the scree plot criterion (Cattell, 1966). The internal consistency of the items will be assessed with Cronbach’s alpha (Cronbach, 1951).

H1: Spearman correlation between frequency of previous lifetime psychedelic use and the primary outcomes measures reported at baseline.

H2: To test H2a and H2b, we will examine changes in political ideology two weeks after a psychedelic experience, relative to the individual’s baseline political ideology (measured one week prior to the experience), in novices and experts. Specifically, we will perform a 2 (Time: pre-, two-weeks) x 4 (Ideology: self-identified liberalism-conservatism, self-identified anti-authoritarianism-authoritarianism, political perspectives, ethical consumerism) x 2 (Previous Experience: novice, expert) mixed MANCOVA, controlling for the demographic variables age, gender, employment-status. Time and ideology measure will be specified as within-subject factors, and previous experience with psychedelics will be specified as a between-subjects factor. Post-hoc t-tests will then be performed to examine any significant effects.

To test H2c we will perform median splits on the baseline level ideology (dependent) variables - self-identified liberalism-conservatism, self-identified anti-authoritarianism-authoritarianism, political perspectives, ethical consumerism – and compare changes in ideology at the two-week timepoint for high and low scorers using independent-samples t-tests.

To check that the results are robust, we will then repeat these analyses using the four-week primary outcome measure, instead of the two-week timepoint scores. 

H3: To test H3a, we will use bivariate correlation analyses to measure the strength of association between the change in the primary outcome measures (self-identified liberalism-conservatism, self-identified anti-authoritarianism-authoritarianism, political perspectives, ethical consumerism) at the two-week timepoint and the corresponding change in each of the following trait variables: empathy, compassion, mindfulness and personality traits (openness, conscientiousness, agreeableness, extraversion and neuroticism). 

To test H3b, we will perform causal mediation analysis to explore whether the effects of psychedelic use on the primary outcome measures at the two-week timepoint are mediated by ego dissolution during the psychedelic experience. 

To test H3c, we will perform the same mediation analysis on two subsets of respondents – novices and experts – and compare the strength of the indirect effect, using confidence intervals to determine statistical significance. 

To check that the results are robust, we will then repeat these analyses using the primary outcome measure scores at the four-week timepoint, instead of the two-week timepoint scores.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<0.5 criteria for determining if the f-tests, t-tests and correlations suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. For the mediation analyses, we will use the confidence intervals of the indirect effect(s) to determine statistical significance.

q24.value: We expect that gratitude and certain set items may be related to the effects of psychedelic drug use on political perspectives and ethical consumerism. Therefore, we will look for relationships between gratitude as well as set items (mood, anxiety, comfort, expectations, intention, openness to the upcoming experience and setting) and the primary outcome measures. We will examine correlations between the primary outcome measures and the subscales of the Interpersonal Reactivity Index. We will also repeat the analyses described above using the two-year post-experience timepoint scores to assess whether there were lasting effects on the sub-sample of respondents who completed the survey items at this stage.

q25.value:
References:

Cattell, R.B. (1966). The scree test for the number of factors. Multivariate Behavioral Research, 1, 245-276.

Cronbach, L. J. (1951). Coefficient alpha and the internal structure of tests. Psychometrika, 16, 297–334.

Davis, M. H. (1983). Measuring individual differences in empathy: Evidence for a multidimensional approach. Journal of personality and social psychology, 44(1), 113.

Hwang, J. Y., Plante, T., & Lackey, K. (2008). The development of the santa clara brief compassion scale: An abbreviation of sprecher and fehr’s compassionate love scale. Pastoral Psychology, 56, 421–428.

H1: Frequency of lifetime psychedelic use at baseline will correlate positively with liberal political perspectives and ethical consumerism scores.

H2a: Psychedelic drug users will have more liberal political perspectives and higher ethical consumerism scores after taking part in the psychedelic session/ceremony/experience relative to pre-experience baseline scores. 
H2b: The effects of psychedelic drug use on political perspectives and ethical consumerism will be stronger for novices, who had little to no previous experience using psychedelics, than for experts who had significant previous experience using psychedelics.
H2c: The effects of psychedelic drug use on political perspectives and ethical consumerism will be greater in participants with lower baseline scores on liberalism, anti-authoritarianism and ethical consumerism.

H3a: Changes in pre-post levels of empathy, compassion, mindfulness and openness (but not conscientiousness, agreeableness, extraversion and neuroticism) will be correlated with changes in political perspectives and ethical consumerism.
H3b: The effects of psychedelic drug use on political perspectives and ethical consumerism will be mediated by changes in ego dissolution during the experience.
H3c: The mediation effect described in H3b will be greater for novices than experts.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q7: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration following analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11: Data was collected as part of a larger study investigating what factors are most influential in determining how people will respond to psychedelic drugs. As of the date of submission, some of the data relevant to the research plan have been accessed and analyzed by the members of the research team who are based at Imperial College London. Crucially, however, the data relevant to the research plan (but no additional data) have not been accessed by the preregistration entrants: Simonsson (University of Oxford) and Marks (University College London).
registration_responses.q13: The aim was to recruit at least 100 participants. However, it was hoped that this number would be exceeded.
registration_responses.q21: We will use the standard p<0.5 criteria for determining if the f-tests, t-tests and correlations suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. For the mediation analyses, we will use the confidence intervals of the indirect effect(s) to determine statistical significance.
registration_responses.q24: We expect that gratitude and certain set items may be related to the effects of psychedelic drug use on political perspectives and ethical consumerism. Therefore, we will look for relationships between gratitude as well as set items (mood, anxiety, comfort, expectations, intention, openness to the upcoming experience and setting) and the primary outcome measures. We will examine correlations between the primary outcome measures and the subscales of the Interpersonal Reactivity Index. We will also repeat the analyses described above using the two-year post-experience timepoint scores to assess whether there were lasting effects on the sub-sample of respondents who completed the survey items at this stage.
registration_responses.q25:
References:

Cattell, R.B. (1966). The scree test for the number of factors. Multivariate Behavioral Research, 1, 245-276.

Cronbach, L. J. (1951). Coefficient alpha and the internal structure of tests. Psychometrika, 16, 297–334.

Davis, M. H. (1983). Measuring individual differences in empathy: Evidence for a multidimensional approach. Journal of personality and social psychology, 44(1), 113.

Feldman, G., Hayes, A., Kumar, S., Greeson, J., & Laurenceau, J.-P. (2007). Mindfulness and emotion regulation: The development and initial validation of the Cognitive and Affective Mindfulness Scale-Revised (CAMS-R). Journal of Psychopathology and Behavioral Assessment, 29(3), 177-190.

Hwang, J. Y., Plante, T., & Lackey, K. (2008). The development of the santa clara brief compassion scale: An abbreviation of sprecher and fehr’s compassionate love scale. Pastoral Psychology, 56, 421–428.

Nour, M. M., Evans, L., Nutt, D., & Carhart-Harris, R. L. (2016). Ego-Dissolution and Psychedelics: Validation of the Ego-Dissolution Inventory (EDI). Frontiers in Human Neuroscience, 10, 269.
registration_responses.q8.question: Observational (pre-post, longitudinal) Study
registration_responses.q12.question:
Psychedelic drug users intent on having a psychedelic experience through their own initiative were informed about the online questionnaire. Volunteers were recruited by posting a link on several online platforms, leading to a website created for this project (www.psychedelicsurvey.com). This website contained information about the study and its purpose, what was expected from the participants and it provided the opportunity to sign up for the study. After reading the study information, individuals who were willing to participate enrolled themselves in the study by declaring informed consent (button click) and entering the expected date of their psychedelic experience.

Participants were measured on six occasions: 1) One week before the psychedelic session/ceremony/experience was due to take place, or as near to the experience as possible (note, due to travel plans and the potential unavailability of internet, individuals may have needed to complete the baseline measures some time before the experience itself, but crucially, the timing was recorded). At this timepoint, demographic information and baseline trait variables were assessed. 2) Within 0-3 hours of the ceremony/dosing session taking place; state variables concerning set were assessed at this point. 3) Within two days of the session/ceremony/experience took place, to assess the setting of the session/ceremony/experience and the acute psychological effects. 4) Two weeks after the session/ceremony/experience took place, to measure long-term effects. 5) Four weeks after the session/ceremony/experience, the trait variables were assessed again as a follow-up procedure. 6) Approximately 24 months after the session/ceremony/experience, the trait variables were assessed again as a follow-up procedure.

Technology was designed for participants to receive the right questionnaires on the appropriate moments through email notifications. Participants consented to receiving these email prompts during the informed consent process.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Demographic information: Age, gender, employment-status

Frequency of lifetime psychedelic use: (categorical response options ranging from 'Never' to '>100 times')

Ego-dissolution: Ego-Dissolution Inventory (EDI) (Nour et al., 2016)

Political perspectives: Political Perspective Questionnaire (PPQ) (self-constructed measure) 

Liberalism to conservatism VAS scale

Anti-authoritarianism to authoritarianism VAS scale

Empathy Interpersonal Reactivity Index (IRI) (Davis, 1983)

Compassion Santa Clara Brief Compassion Scale (SCBCS) (Hwang, Plante, & Lackey, 2008)

Mindfulness Cognitive and Affective Mindfulness Scale – revised (CAMS-R) (Feldman, Hayes, Kumar, Greeson, & Laurenceau, 2007)
registration_responses.q18.question:
A scale was devised to measure concern regarding ethical consumerism. The ethical consumerism scale will be subjected to an exploratory factor analysis using principal component analysis (PCA). The appropriate number of factors to be extracted will be
determined by the scree plot criterion (Cattell, 1966). The internal consistency of the items will be assessed with Cronbach’s alpha (Cronbach, 1951).
registration_responses.q19.question:
H1: Spearman correlation between frequency of previous lifetime psychedelic use and the primary outcomes measures reported at baseline.

H2: To test H2a and H2b, we will examine changes in political ideology two weeks after a psychedelic experience, relative to the individual’s baseline political ideology (measured one week prior to the experience), in novices and experts. Specifically, we will perform a 2 (Time: pre-, two-weeks) x 4 (Ideology: self-identified liberalism-conservatism, self-identified anti-authoritarianism-authoritarianism, political perspectives, ethical consumerism) x 2 (Previous Experience: novice, expert) mixed MANCOVA, controlling for the demographic variables age, gender, employment-status. Time and ideology measure will be specified as within-subject factors, and previous experience with psychedelics will be specified as a between-subjects factor. Post-hoc t-tests will then be performed to examine any significant effects.

To test H2c we will perform median splits on the baseline level ideology (dependent) variables - self-identified liberalism-conservatism, self-identified anti-authoritarianism-authoritarianism, political perspectives, ethical consumerism – and compare changes in ideology at the two-week timepoint for high and low scorers using independent-samples t-tests.

To check that the results are robust, we will then repeat these analyses using the four-week primary outcome measure, instead of the two-week timepoint scores. 

H3: To test H3a, we will use bivariate correlation analyses to measure the strength of association between the change in the primary outcome measures (self-identified liberalism-conservatism, self-identified anti-authoritarianism-authoritarianism, political perspectives, ethical consumerism) at the two-week timepoint and the corresponding change in each of the following trait variables: empathy, compassion, mindfulness and personality traits (openness, conscientiousness, agreeableness, extraversion and neuroticism). 

To test H3b, we will perform causal mediation analysis to explore whether the effects of psychedelic use on the primary outcome measures at the two-week timepoint are mediated by ego dissolution during the psychedelic experience. 

To test H3c, we will perform the same mediation analysis on two subsets of respondents – novices and experts – and compare the strength of the indirect effect, using confidence intervals to determine statistical significance. 

To check that the results are robust, we will then repeat these analyses using the primary outcome measure scores at the four-week timepoint, instead of the two-week timepoint scores.

attributes.title: Effect of discourse factors on perspective

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: effect of discourse factors on perspective

other.value: Demographic data (age, gender, location) will also be collected.

sample.value: 64 participants (not counted excluded participants) will be included.

analyses.value:
We will conduct the following pairwise comparisons:

(1) Rate of 'come' answers when the first-mentioned entity is named versus unnamed.
(2) Rate of 'come' answers when the second-mentioned entity is named versus unnamed.
(3) Rate of 'come' answers when the second-mentioned entity is the subject versus the object in the second sentence.

We will run t-tests to test the significance of these comparisons. We will also fit a mixed effects model on the results using the maximal random effects structure.

outliers.value:
24 fillers are included, in 4 categories: hard, easy, modal, and negative-polarity items. Participants who fail to answer correctly at least 80% of the easy, modal, and NPI fillers will be excluded.
Participants who indicate that they are not monolingual American English speakers will also be excluded. 
Participants whose responses to the debriefing question seem non-human will be excluded as well.
(For instance, when asked, "What is your favorite insult?", if a participant responses 'Yes', they will be excluded.)

dependent.value:
In the experiment, participants will read 3 sentence discourses. The verb of the last sentence will be missing, and participants will indicate whether 'come' or 'go' sounds more natural. The key dependent variable is the rate of 'come' and 'go' completions.

An example discourse is as follows:

[A man / Andy] had a couple of apple trees that were thriving. 

[He knew that] [One of his neighbors / Sarah] loved apples. 

Because there were so many,  [she/he]  ______ over to see if he would share.

conditions.value:
There are 8 conditions, based on crossing (1) whether the first entity in the discourse is named; (2) whether the second entity is named; and (3) whether the second entity is the subject of the second sentence. In addition, we will observe participant behavior in each of these conditions in two ways: (1) in contexts where the subject of the 3rd sentence is the first-entity and (2) in contexts where the subject of the 3rd sentence is the second-entity.

So, there are 16 narrative structures, but 2 x 2 x 2 discourse effects being manipulated.

Participants will be assigned evenly across conditions using a Latin square design.

hypothesis.value:
What effect do discourse factors like subjecthood, namedness, and first-mentionhood have on the use of perspectival motion verbs?

There are many contexts in which either 'come' or 'go' can be used. The adoption of a particular perspective depends on the discourse prominence of the perspective-holder, but how is this prominence determined?

We plan to look at three discourse factors: (1) whether the perspective-holder is the subject of the preceding sentence, (2) whether the perspective-holder has been named in the discourse, and (3) whether the perspective-holder is the first-mentioned person in the discourse.

attributes.title: Mirror imaging fallacy and its effect on rapport-building

q1.value: Mirror imaging fallacy and its effect on rapport building

q3.value:
An inductive, qualitative data analysis found several cognitive biases and logical fallacies to affect effective rapport-building in negative ways. 

In a simulated hostage negotiation, crisis negotiators have been found to attempt to de-escalate and build rapport with the perpetrator by addressing her within the same frame of reference through which they themselves interpreted their experiences and their environment.

With a different cultural and ideological background, perpetrators escalated and reacted with increased emotional intensity to corresponding statements by the crisis negotiators.

This study now attempts to investigate the level of awareness among crisis negotiators, who are professionally and frequently trained in interpersonal and de-escalating communication, of the mirror imaging fallacy and the risks it poses to effective rapport building.

q4.value:
1. Crisis negotiators are not aware of the mirror imaging fallacy (or statements that represent this cognitive bias).
2. A brief communicative intervention will make crisis negotiators aware of the mirror imaging fallacy.
3. A brief communicative intervention will motivate crisis negotiators to communicate cognizant of and to avoid the mirror imaging fallacy in the future.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Semi-structured interviews and semi-structured group interviews. No counter-balancing required.

q9.value: The study does not employ randomization at any stage.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Subjects are sworn police officers who are formally qualified and trained crisis negotiators. 
Subjects have been recruited through a research cooperation with their institutions, which are formally (by contract) agreed upon research cooperation partners.
Participation will be strictly voluntary and only possible after individually granted, informed consent. 
Participation will be anonymous and governed by local information processing, data protection, and privacy legislation and guidelines. 
The University of Liverpool Institute of Life Sciences internal review board has approved of the study. 
Data collection (interviews) will be conducted on Monday, 2020-01-13, Tuesday, 2020-01-14, and Wednesday, 2020-01-15.

q13.value: The total number of participants will include between 10 and 20.

q14.value: The sample size will be limited by the overall number of crisis negotiators with the partnering institutions and their availability, depending on the services' situational and operational needs at the time of the data collection.

q15.value: Scheduling guarantees that all available, registered participants will be interviewed.

question.value:
V1: awareness of the mirror imaging fallacy
Manipulation: brief communicative intervention = presentation of the mirror imaging fallacy and discussion of how its workings and effects on building rapport.

V2: willingness to communicate cognizant of and avoid mirror imaging fallacy
Questionnaire at the end of the interview.
qualitative data analysis/content analysis approach since this is a small-n study
